A translator, however, although he would prefer to spend all his time and care on 1113 proper task of translating, is sometimes compelled to defend a new reading or suggest an emendation, because in his opinion such a course is required by the sense of the passage. But the extra cautiori neces- sary in these cases has made me refrain from mention- ing some emendations of my own that I thought possible or even likely. It is, moreover, often for- gotten that an ancient author—and this perhaps applies especially to Pliny—may himself have made mistakes, even bad ones, that escaped the notice of his corrector, if he had one.
